name: Japanese Omelet
instruction:
Step 1: Cook steamed rice. 

Step 2: Cut chicken into small pieces. 

Step 3: Chop green pepper. 

Step 4: Slice mushrooms thinly. 

Step 5: Heat vegetable oil in a large skillet and pan fry chicken. Add onion, mushrooms, and green pepper to the skillet and pan fry together. 

Step 6: Add steamed rice to the skillet and stir-fry together. Sprinkle salt and pepper. Stop the heat, add ketchup and mix. set the seasoned rice aside. 

Step 7: Heat 1 tp of vegetable oil in a large skillet. Beat two eggs nd pour into the skillet. Spread the egg and make a omelet. 

Step 8: Place 1/4 of the seasoned rice in the middle of the omelet. Fold top and bottom sides of omelet over the rice. Cover the frying pan with a plate and turn them over to place the omurice in the plate. 

Step 9: Repeat this process to make four omurices. 

Step 10: Serve and top with ketcup (optional)
tip: To complete your meal, consider adding 1/4 more pound of veggies including steamed broccoli and/or carrots

name: Soba Noodles
instruction:
Step 1: Cook, drain and rinse noodles. 

Step 2: Add sauce, stir and let soak in. 

Step 3: Sprinkle with sesame seeds and green onions.
tip: To complete your meal, consider adding 1/2 plate amount of veggies, and 1/4 plate amount of meat or alternative

name: Chirashi Zushi
instruction:
Step 1: Prepare sushi rice. 

Step 2:  Remove stems from shiitake and slice thinly. 

Step 3:  Heat 2/3 cup of the water used for rehydrating shiitake in a medium pan. 

Step 4: Add shiitake, soy sauce, sugar, and mirin. 

Step 5: Simmer shiitake on low heat until the liquid is almost gone. 

Step 6:  Beat eggs in a bowl and add 1/2 Tbsp of sugar. 

Step 7:  Oil a medium skillet and pour a scoop of egg mixture and make a thin omelette like a crape. 

Step 8: Make a few sheets. Cut the omelettes into thin strips. 

 Step 9: Serve sushi rice on a large plate or individual bowls. 

Step 10: Spread simmered shiitake, cucumber, imitation crab meat, and omelettes strips over rice. 

Step 11: Place tuna sashimi on top. Sprinkle sesame seeds. Serve pickled ginger on the side.
tip: To complete your meal, consider adding 1/2 plate amount of veggies, and 1/2 plate amount of meat or alternative

name: Okonomi Yaki
instruction:
Step 1: Mix together the veggies. 

Step 2: Mix together the remaining ingredients to form a smooth, pourable batter. 

Step 3: Mix the veggies into the batter. The mixture should be of a consistency that you can spoon the patties onto the skillet. If it is not, adjust with either water or flour. 

Step 4: Drop spoonfuls of batter (approx. 3 tbsp per patty) onto a heated, oiled skillet over medium heat. 

Step 5: Brown well on one side, then flip and brown on the other. 

Step 6: Serve hot or cold.
tip: To complete your meal, consider adding 1/4 plate amount of grain, and 1/4 plate amount of meat or alternative

name: Daikon Zosui
instruction:
Step 1: Peel the daikon and carrot, and slice into two-inch-long by one-half-inch wide ribbons that are no more than one-eighth-inch thick. 

Step 2: The easiest way to accomplish this is by just using your vegetable peeler. 

Step 3: In a stockpot or large saucepan, heat the stock over medium-high heat. 

Step 4: Add the daikon and carrot, and cook until the vegetables have softened, about 10 minutes. 

Step 5: Add the cooked rice, mushrooms and wakame, and bring to a boil again, stirring occasionally. 

Step 6: Stir in salt and soy sauce and serve imdediately. 

Step 7: Be careful not to cook the rice too long; otherwise, it will end up the unappetizing consistency of glue.
tip: To complete your meal, consider adding 1/2 plate amount of veggie, and 1/4 plate amount of meat or alternative

name: Cucumbers with Soy Sesame Dressing
instruction:
Step 1: In a bowl, combine the potatoe vinegar, peanut oil, soy sauce, sesame oil, crushed red pepper and sugar (optional). Whisk well. 

Step 2: Add cucumbers and red onion. Toss them in the dressing. 

Step 3: Cover and chill for 24 hours to 48 hours. 

Step 4: To serve, sprinkle with toasted pumpkin seeds and chopped onions.
tip: To complete your meal, consider adding 1/4 plate amount of grain, and 1/4 plate amount of meat

name: Broccoli Goma-ae
instruction:
Step 1: Bring water to a boil in a saucepan. 

Step 2: Add broccoli and cook for one minute. 

Step 3: Prepare sesame seeds by putting them in a covered, dry frying pan and toasting them over medium heat, shaking the pan constantly so that seeds do not burn. 

Step 4: When seeds turn golden brown (about 3 minutes) remove the pan from the heat. Place seeds in a small bowl and crush lightly with the back of a large spoon, or process in a blender for a few seconds. 

Step 5: Combine soy sauce, sugar, and sesame seeds and mix well. Toss with broccoli and serve.
tip: To complete your meal, consider adding 1/4 plate amount of grain, and 1/4 plate amount of meat or alternative

name: Cucumber with Crab Sunomono
instruction:
Step 1: Thinly slice cucumbers, place in bowl, and sprinkle with salt. Let stand for 5 minutes, then use your hands to gently squeeze water out of cucumbers. 

Step 2: Break crab into small pieces. 

Step 3: In another bowl, combine vinegar, sugar, and soy sauce. 

Step 4: Put cucumber and crab in 4 small bowls and pour on dressing. Sprinkle with sesame seeds, if desired.
tip: To complete your meal, consider adding 1/4 plate amount of grain, and 1/4 plate amount of meat or alternative

name: Japanese Simmered Beef and Vegetables - Sukiyaki
instruction:
Step 1: Slice beef very thinly. 

Step 2: Heat oil in frying pan and saute beef. 

Step 3: Add scallions, shirataki, bamboo shoots, mushrooms, and tofu. 

Step 4: Combine remaining ingredients to make a sauce. Pour sauce over meat and vegetables until they are half covered. 

Step 5: Adjust heat so that sauce simmers.After about 10 minutes, test a piece of meat to see if it is done. 

Step6: Remove from pan and serve with hot rice
tip: To complete your meal, consider adding 1/4 plate amount of grain

name: Japanese Noodles - Menrui
instruction:
Step 1: Bring water to a boil. Add noodles and return water to a boil, stirring occasionally. Cook for about 20 minutes or until noodles are soft. 

Step 2: Drain noodles in a colander and rinse in cold water to stop the cooking process. 

Step 3: For hot noodles: set noodles aside and prepare broth. 

Step 4: For cold noodles: put noodles in refrigerator to cool while preparing the dipping sauce. 

Step 5: Combine all broth ingredients in a pan and bring to a boil. Add noodles and bring to a boil again to heat noodles. 

Step 6: Remove from heat and serve noodles with broth in 4 individual bowls. 

Step 7: Top noodles with chopped scallions or dried red pepper flakes, if desired. 

Step 8: For dipping sauce mix together all ingredients
tip: To complete your meal, consider adding 1/4 plate amount of meat or alternative

name: Oyako Donburi
instruction:
Step 1: Cut chicken into small pieces. Beat in a bowl the eggs. 

Step 2: Dust chicken pieces with flour, dip in beaten egg (reserve extra), and fry on both sides in hot oil until brown. 

Step 3: Combine in saucepan the water and mushrooms. Simmer 10 minutes, remove mushrooms, and cut fine. 

Step 3: Add to skillet the mushrooms and liquid, sugar and soy. Simmer 15 minutes. Add scallions. Simmer 10 more minutes. Add spinach. 

Step 4: While spinach is still bright green, add reserved beaten eggs to skillet and cover. Cook briefly, just until set. 

Step 5: Ladle over individual rice servings in bowls and top with chopped parsley.
tip: To complete your meal, consider adding 1/4 plate amount of grain, and 1/4 plate amount of meat or alternative

name: Yakisoba
instruction:
Step 1: Cut the cabbage, carrot, and pork into bite sizes. Saute cabbage, carrot, and pork in a large frying pan. 

Step 2: Add yakisoba noodles in the pan. Put 1/2 cup of water in the pan and cover it with a lid. Take the lid off and add yakisoba seasoning mix or yakisoba sauce. 

Step 3: Stir the noodles well and fry them for a few minutes. Sprinkle aonori, and beni-shoga over the noodles before serving.
tip: To complete your meal, consider adding 1/2 plate amount of veggie, and 1/4 plate amount of meat or alternative

name: Japanese Bean Paste Soup - Misoshiru
instruction:
Step 1: In a saucepan, bring water to a boil and stir in dashinomoto and miso. 

Step 2: Add tofu and bring mixture to a boil again. 

Step 3: Remove from heat, pour into 4 small bowls, and garnish with scallions.
tip: To complete your meal, consider adding 1/4 plate amount of grain

name: Japanese Eggdrop Soup - Tamago Toji
instruction:
Step 1: Beat egg and scallions together in a small bowl. 

Step 2: In a saucepan, bring basic clear soup to a boil. 

Step 3: In a saucepan, bring basic clear soup to a boil. 

Step 4: Remove soup from heat and pour into 4 small bowls to serve.
tip: To complete your meal, consider adding 1/2 plate amount of veggies, and 1/4 plate amount of grain

name: Japanese Eggplant Miso Soup
instruction:
Step 1: In boiling wash, add miso. 

Step 2: Mash to dissolve. 

Step 3: Add carrots, scallions, tofu and eggplant. 

Step 4: Cook until veggies are tender.
tip: To complete your meal, consider adding 1/4 plate amount of grain, and 1/4 plate amount of meat and alternatives

name: Stir-fried Japanese Eggplant with Ginger and Miso
instruction:
Step 1: Stir the miso and the sake together in a small bowl, set aside. 

Step 2: Slice the eggplants in half lengthwise. Then slice them on a diagonal, crosswise, in a little less than 1/2-inch thick slices. 

Step 3: Heat the chilies in the oil in a wok or large skillet on medium heat. Once the chilies start to sizzle, and you can smell the aroma of the chilies, add the ginger and eggplant slices, and toss to coat with the oil. Stir gently for several minutes until the eggplant pieces are shiny and soft. 

Step 4: Add the miso-sake mixture to the eggplant pieces and gently stir to coat. Remove from heat. Stir in the chopped shiso, Thai basil, or mint leaves, and serve immediately.
tip: To complete your meal, consider adding 1/4 plate amount of grain, and 1/4 plate amount of meat

name: Chicken Ramen
instruction:
Step 1: In a large saucepan over medium heat, heat the oil. Add the scallions, garlic, carrot, mushrooms, and cabbage. Cook, stirring often, for 3 minutes, or until the vegetables soften. Stir in the ginger and brown sugar and cook for 30 seconds. Finally add the chicken broth and bring to a simmer. Simmer for 10 minutes. 

Step 2: While the broth is simmering, bring a pot of water to a boil. Set a bowl of cold ice water nearby. Use a slotted spoon to gently lower the eggs, still in the shell, into the water. Simmer for 7 minutes for eggs that are soft and a little runny in the center, or 9 minutes for hard-boiled eggs. Transfer the eggs to the bowl of cold water and set aside until ready to serve. 

Step 3: Return the pot of water to a boil. Add the noodles and cook for 3 minutes, or according to the package directions, until tender. Drain in a colander. 

Step 4: Divide the noodles among 4 large bowls. Ladle the broth and vegetables over the noodles. Remove the eggs from the ice water. Tap the shells with a spoon to crack and then peel off the shells. Pat the eggs dry and cut them in half. Top each bowl with the egg halves and the sliced chicken. Serve with soy sauce, hot sauce, cilantro leaves and lime wedges.
tip: To complete your meal, consider adding 1/4 plate amount of grain
